title: WWE's Lacey Evans wants to 'change world' as she's confirmed Saudi Arabia match
text:
Lacey Evans is about to change the world through WWE (Picture: WWE)

Lacey Evans wants to change the world and use her WWE platform to create a positive, shining light for people suffering in the dark.

The so-called sassy southern belle will make history on Thursday night when she faces former champion Natalya in the first ever women’s match in Saudi Arabia at Crown Jewel in Riyadh.

Speaking to Metro.co.uk in Los Angeles before the announcement was made, Lacey said: ‘When I signed up for WWE my goal was to really impact the world and the people that I can, and we’re doing it one day at a time.’

Advertisement

The groundbreaking bout was confirmed on Wednesday morning, and the 29-year-old performer – who turned to wrestling after spending time as a military police officer in the US marines – will continue to thrive in a position where she can realise her goal of helping others.

Lacey has been very honest about her mental health struggles and tough upbringing, but she wants to use her own experiences to inspire other people.

‘There’s a lot of people that are going through things that I went through, terrible things growing up,’ she candidly shared. ‘They question themselves, they question their futures, and I’ve been there. To think that I can possibly help and impact the people going through stuff like that is incredible to me.’

Lacey was confirmed for the first female wrestling match in Saudi Arabia today (Picture: WWE)

The star – who would like to conduct seminars to help inspire young women and college students – is proud of having the opportunity to use her platform to make a real, positive change for fans around the world.

And she pointed out that it’s a chance given to her by WWE, as the stars find themselves in a unique position to engage with people in a way other performers don’t always get to do.

‘People are hurting, they’re suffering, they’re tired, they wanna give up. Drug addiction, depression – this is stuff that people face. Mental instability, people face this every single day,’ she added.

‘To think that as a sports entertainer – or someone who has been through that – I can stand up and tell them that this too shall pass, that this isn’t how your life will be as long as you wanna change it. We have the voice to say those things and I love it.’

Lacey Evans’ dreams expand beyond the ring (Picture: WWE)

On screen, Lacey plays an arrogant, determined and outspoken character – and she admitted there has to be an element of truth to any in-ring alter ego for fans to really engage.

Advertisement

However, when it comes to her career goals, Lacey insisted her real focus isn’t on fame and in-ring “success”, but instead her dreams go far deeper.

“I would like to see it impact and help the depression and addiction side of life because that hits me so hard. My hardest days in WWE, when I’m tired, when I’m the most sore, that’s what I always revert back to and keep in my mind,’ she said. ‘That’s my mission.’

‘Yeah, I’d love to be in the Hall of Fame, I’d love to make people remember the WWE superstar, but at the end of the day if they can just remember what Lacey Evans stood for in regards to a hard life and making people realise that it does not matter where you come from – you can do anything…

‘You need to get up, wash your face and battle the day – literally. That’s how you’re gonna be successful. Not money wise, I’m talking about successful, not depressed. I’m talking about successful, not sitting in a dark room because there’s no reason to get up. When you can find happiness, that’s success – and that’s my goal.’

*Friday Night SmackDown airs every week at 1am on Sky Sports Arena and Main Event. WWE will be touring the UK next month with a huge double TV taping featuring both Raw and SmackDown superstars in Manchester on 8 November.
description: WWE's Lacey Evans wants to 'change the world' as she makes history with Saudi Arabia match.
